content: Decades of federal policymaking emphasize the importance of quality instruction for student learning. The Higher Education Act of 1965 includes provisions in Title II, Part A to improve teacher preparation programs through financial support and accountability measures. This includes a competitive grant program for program reforms and reporting requirements for states to track and report on teacher preparation program quality. The 115th Congress is considering a reauthorization of the Higher Education Act (HEA), with one bill proposing to repeal all provisions in Title II and another bill seeking to amend and extend Title II. The authorization of appropriations for Title II-A expired in FY2011 and was extended for an additional fiscal year. The authorization of appropriations for Title II-A expired in FY2011 and was extended for an additional fiscal year under the General Education Provisions Act. Title II-A authorities have continued to be funded under various appropriations legislation, most recently under P.L. 115-245 for FY2019. Congressional action to reauthorize the HEA may continue, with key issues identified for debate. Title II-A of the HEA includes a competitive grant program, the Teacher Quality Partnership (TQP) program, which aims to improve teacher preparation and support professional development activities for new teachers. The TQP program funds traditional pre-baccalaureate or fifth-year teacher preparation programs and teacher residency programs. The Teacher Quality Partnership (TQP) program aims to improve teacher preparation and support professional development for new teachers through traditional pre-baccalaureate or fifth-year programs and teacher residency programs. The program receives annual appropriations of about $42 million, supporting grants to around two dozen partnerships. Approximately 30% of awarded projects are pre-baccalaureate/fifth year programs, 48% are residency programs, and 23% are a combination of both.
